results.title: Land of the hornbill
results.creator_credit: Ow Kheng Law, B.H. Hipkins and Malayan Film Unit
results.brief_description: A picture of life in the colony of Sarawak, youngest of the British protectorates and the home of the head-hunting Dyaks. With the discovery and production of oil, much industrial progress has been made - progress which often contrasts sharply with the ancient crafts. The film shows the living conditions, the production of sago by old and new methods, the growing of pepper, and the immensely important oil industry.

results.title: Land of the dancing shiva
results.creator_credit: R Bacha, Documentary Films of India, DRD Productions and Film Group of India
results.brief_description: The Bharat Natyam dance form of South India. Temple sculptures reveal the antiquity of this dance, which is an exposition of Hindu mythology. The first part of the film describes the temples of South India, and the second shows a professional temple dancer performing before the statue of Shiva.

results.title: Land of the Brahmaputra
results.brief_description: The people of the plains of the Brahmaputra, an ancient river highway, with a tragic history of floods. The valley people; religion, agriculture, silk spinning; family life, the marriage rites; the market place; the capital of an ancient kingdom; the plantations; the growth of secondary industries; the elephants of Assam.

results.title: Land of the borders
results.creator_credit: Simon Crouch and Border Television PLC
results.brief_description: This tape comprises of two parts; the Battlegrounds, and Eastern Borders, as Melvyn Bragg explores the wild and empty landscapes sprinkled with castles, fortresses and abbeys that provide the backdrop to Europe’s turbulent history. In the Battleground section, Bragg traces the forces and events that shaped the lives of those from the Western Borders. He visits Hadrian’s Wall, Carlisle Castle, Lanercost Priory, Caerlaverock Castle, Burgh by Sands, the Lochmabonstane truce site, Hermitage Castle, plus many other key locations. In the Eastern Borders section Bragg considers the influence of religion and the sea. Beginning with the founding of the monastery on Holy Island, the sea meanwhile provided people with a living as well as a source of disaster and heroism. Places visited include The Holy Island, Norham Castle, Melrose Abbey, the River Tweed, the Yetholm Show, battleground and memorial at Flodden, Alnwick Castle, plus many other sites from the region.

results.title: Land of magic
results.creator_credit: Eric Fullilove, Terry Ashwood and Associated British-Pathe
results.brief_description: The scenic beauties, history, and holiday amenities of Northern Ireland. Ulster, the green land, is rich in unspoilt countryside; a sportman’s paradise with ample facilities for tennis and walking, golf an fishing. The unique pilgrimage to Country Down, the majestic castle at Derry, the Mountains of Mourne, and the markets and entertainments of Belfast are shown in the film.

results.title: Land of hype and glory
results.creator_credit: Tom Priestly, Karen Lerner and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: This film focuses on two markets - literary and cinema - to show how the public is manipulated by extravagant promotion. Many tools are used by publishers to help create best-sellers, and movie hype is big business.

results.title: Land of enlightenment
results.creator_credit: Mohan Wadhwani, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: This film follows the progress of a Chinese pilgrim through the blessed land of Bihar, “The Land of Englightenment”, which was once the centre of learning and worship for students of Central Asia, China, Burma and Ceylon; the land where Buddha was born. Every pillar, arch and relic from Sarnath, Sonapur and Patna, Nalanda and Vaishali, Pavapuri, and Bodh Gaya to Rajgir, speak of the message of Sakyamuni to the devout pilgrim.

results.title: Land of Cyprus
results.brief_description: Shows how timber-getting, grazing of goats, wind and water have all contributed to the problem of soil erosion in Cyprus. Explains how the British Government is tackling the problem; building dams, developing irrigation methods, stamping out malarial mosquitoes, teaching contour ploughing and terracing, planting new forests. The film mentions the difficulties of over-crowded towns and increasing population.
